IV.i.3.B.1.c
.
Hearing Loss and Tinnitus Examination Report Review
A hearing loss and tinnitus examination report may be considered insufficient if an opinion was requested but is not provided in the report.
Unusual circumstances may arise during the examination, requiring the examiner to
identify any audiometric frequencies that could not be tested (CNT) and explain why testing could not be done
provide an explanation of why speech discrimination testing was not performed on the Veteran, or why a speech discrimination score is not appropriate in the Veteran's case, and/or
state the functional impact of tinnitus.
Note
:  In a case involving service connection (SC) for hearing loss where an etiology opinion is required, the examiner’s rationale should not
solely
discuss that hearing was normal at the times of the Veteran’s enlistment and separation.
When there is a current diagnosis of hearing loss, the examiner should provide an explanation as to how the provided opinion was reached.  This includes discussing pertinent objective evidence, lay testimony from the Veteran, and scientific literature that either refutes or supports a relationship between the current hearing loss and an event, injury, or disease during military service.
Decision makers should
not
deny SC for hearing loss based on an examiner’s medical opinion rationale which
solely
discusses that hearing was normal during service to support a conclusion that the current hearing loss is not related to service.  The examination report should be returned due to an insufficient medical opinion rationale.
References
:  For more information on
requesting audiometric examinations and medical opinions, see
M21-1, Part V, Subpart iii, 2.B.1.d
, and
the requirement for a supporting rationale for medical opinions, see
M21-1, Part V, Subpart ii, 1.A.3.g
.
